GENERAL DIRECTIONS
Arrangement of Information
1. First, group your rate-card information
under the sections shown on the sample
cards.
Include each of the sections. Keep the
same order, and do not combine or omit
sections.
2. Repeat information, if necessary, in dif¬
ferent sections; or give a cross-reference to
the item number where the information is
first stated.
3. Describe each item clearly. For example,
under 13 (d), print “Depth of column
12% inches,” rather than “12% inches.”
Specifications for Printing
4. The card should measure 6x3% inches to
facilitate filing.
5. 120 pound Bristol Board is recommended.
6. Use black ink and at least 6 point type for
clarity and readability.
7. Arrange information in two columns read¬
ing from the top to the bottom of the
card. Or, if you prefer, in two columns
within horizontal rules.
8. The rate card may be single or multiple
paged. (See model cards).
In printing a double card, leave a strip of
blank space on the reverse side where the
fold occurs. The fold should occur at the
bottom of the card.
Print card so that it “tumbles” — that is,
when it is turned over, top to bottom, the
reading is continuous.
Index Line at Top of Card
9. Center the publication name on the index
line. Logotype of name may be used; also,
insignia of media associations and audit¬
ing organizations.
10. At the far left, show the frequency of issue,
name of publishing company, the address
and the telephone number of the publica¬
tion.
Numbering of Rate Cards
11. In the upper right corner, show the num¬
ber, the issue date and the effective date
of the rate card.
12. Number successive rate cards consecu¬
tively. A card showing a change in only
one or two items, however, may be indi¬
cated by using the number of the last rate
card plus a letter suffix (for example: Sa).
When this scheme is used, each whole num¬
ber will represent a rate card substantially
different from the previous card.
